pullrequest.title: Added normals in depth camera sensor

content.html:
here’s a check to make sure images are received and the callbacks are called:

diff -r 11f4a1abdb9d gazebo/sensors/DepthCameraSensor_TEST.cc
--- a/gazebo/sensors/DepthCameraSensor_TEST.cc  Tue Feb 04 12:03:51 2020 +0100
+++ b/gazebo/sensors/DepthCameraSensor_TEST.cc  Mon Feb 10 17:52:54 2020 -0800
@@ -149,6 +149,7 @@
       }
     }
   }
+  g_depthCounter++;
 }

 /////////////////////////////////////////////////
@@ -183,6 +184,9 @@
       std::placeholders::_2, std::placeholders::_3, std::placeholders::_4,
       std::placeholders::_5));

+  g_depthCounter = 0u;
+  double updateRate = sensor->UpdateRate();
+  EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(10.0, updateRate);
   // wait for a few depth camera frames
   int i = 0;
   while ( i < 300)
@@ -190,6 +194,7 @@
     common::Time::MSleep(10);
     i++;
   }
+  EXPECT_GE(g_depthCounter, 3 * updateRate);
 }

‌

pullrequest.title: Added normals in depth camera sensor

content.raw: When there is no object, the value that the normal returns is the maximum distance allowed in the sdf. In this test we only want to check the normals on the surface of the box.

pullrequest.title: Added normals in depth camera sensor

content.raw: ah ok got it. I think we should return more meaningful values when there is not data associated with the pixel. The \`farClip value is returned due to [this line](https://bitbucket.org/ahcorde/gazebo/src/34fa76f7bd5110f83b9241fa8852de80beed4888/gazebo/rendering/DepthCamera.cc#lines-342). Could you update it to return zeros when the normal render target is being updated? Without changing the `UpdateRenderTarget` function arguments, we may have to use a variable that gets set before and after the `UpdateRenderTarget` call to indicate what background color to set to depending on the render target. thanks
content.html: ah ok got it. I think we should return more meaningful values when there is not data associated with the pixel. The `farClip value is returned due to this line. Could you update it to return zeros when the normal render target is being updated? Without changing the UpdateRenderTarget function arguments, we may have to use a variable that gets set before and after the UpdateRenderTarget call to indicate what background color to set to depending on the render target. thanks

pullrequest.title: Added normals in depth camera sensor

content.html:
we can probably relax the check for number of msgs received and just have logic to make sure images are received:

diff -r ababc972854c gazebo/sensors/DepthCameraSensor_TEST.cc
--- a/gazebo/sensors/DepthCameraSensor_TEST.cc  Thu Feb 13 10:39:20 2020 +0100
+++ b/gazebo/sensors/DepthCameraSensor_TEST.cc  Fri Feb 14 13:14:50 2020 -0800
@@ -178,16 +178,15 @@
       std::placeholders::_2, std::placeholders::_3, std::placeholders::_4,
       std::placeholders::_5));

-  double updateRate = sensor->UpdateRate();
-  EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(10.0, updateRate);
   // wait for a few depth camera frames
   int i = 0;
-  while (i < 300)
+  unsigned int framesToWait = 10;
+  while (i < 300 && g_normalsCounter < 10)
   {
-    common::Time::MSleep(10);
+    common::Time::MSleep(20);
     i++;
   }
-  EXPECT_GE(g_normalsCounter, 3 * updateRate);
+  EXPECT_GE(g_normalsCounter, framesToWait);
 }

‌

pullrequest.title: Added normals in depth camera sensor

content.html:
My worry is that we may never be entering this if statement.. We require that z > 0.0, but then below check that EXPECT_NEAR(z, -1.0, 0.01), so if we enter the if, the test should fail, right?

If we expect only 2 results, either background or box, we could check that explicitly. For example:

EXPECT_NEAR(x, 0.0, 0.01);
EXPECT_NEAR(y, 0.0, 0.01);
// box
if (z < -0.5)
  EXPECT_NEAR(z, -1.0, 0.01);
// background
else
  EXPECT_NEAR(z, 0.0, 0.01);

pullrequest.title: Added normals in depth camera sensor

content.raw:
Yup, I appreciate the consistency, but we can't add more private members to this class after it's been released, because that would break any downstream code that inherits from it, such as the ROS plugin.

[Here](https://community.kde.org/Policies/Binary_Compatibility_Issues_With_C%2B%2B#Adding_new_data_members_to_classes_without_d-pointer)'s an example of the approach I was referring to above. That example uses Qt types, but you could do the same using a static `std::map`. Let me know if you have any questions.
content.html:
Yup, I appreciate the consistency, but we can't add more private members to this class after it's been released, because that would break any downstream code that inherits from it, such as the ROS plugin.

Here's an example of the approach I was referring to above. That example uses Qt types, but you could do the same using a static std::map. Let me know if you have any questions.

pullrequest.title: Added normals in depth camera sensor

content.raw:
`gl_FragColor` expects `vec4` so we’ll need to set it to that type in the shaders. 

As for the texture format, we are using `PF_FLOAT32_RGBA` so it is indeed storing the extra unused `1.0` value.  That’s mainly because I remember there was a problem with `PF_FLOAT32_RGB` floating point texture formats on certain graphics cards. So to be safe, `RGBA` is used.
content.html:
gl_FragColor expects vec4 so we’ll need to set it to that type in the shaders.

As for the texture format, we are using PF_FLOAT32_RGBA so it is indeed storing the extra unused 1.0 value. That’s mainly because I remember there was a problem with PF_FLOAT32_RGB floating point texture formats on certain graphics cards. So to be safe, RGBA is used.
